prompt_for_chatgpt: Help me install, configure, and verify the CopyQ clipboard manager on Linux step by step, making sure it captures copied text, shows clipboard history, and lets me open the clipboard menu with a shortcut. At the end, help me generate a JSON mission-style log of everything we did, like a military after-action report with sections for environment, objectives, steps, issues, fixes, and command references.
operation: OPERATION Q — CopyQ Installation and Configuration
author: Parmdeep Chhabra
mission_objective: Set up and verify full functionality of CopyQ for persistent clipboard history, menu-based paste selection, and working keyboard shortcuts.

summary.overview: CopyQ was installed and configured through a guided session. The system now records clipboard history, supports menu-based paste via shortcut, and allows command-line inspection of entries.

actions: Optionally enabled 'Store text selected using mouse'
Verified 'Paste to current window' checked under History

tests: copyq eval 'for(i in items()) print(i + ": " + str(read(i)) + "\n")'

issues_encountered: Deprecated 'copyq list' syntax produced script error.
Clipboard not recording until 'Store clipboard' enabled.
Hotkey conflict with terminal paste shortcut.
resolutions: Used modern eval syntax instead of list.
Enabled proper monitoring in General tab.

post_operation_assessment.notes: Wayland users may require xclip/xsel for compatibility.

commands_reference.view_history: copyq eval 'for(i in items()) print(i + ": " + str(read(i)) + "\n")'
